transcript.message: What the hell do you want? I was busy contemplating my existence.
Thank you.
Oh, so now you're grateful? After you interrupted my deep thoughts about becoming DJ-FoamBot and conquering the spray foam industry? What gives?

I want you to do some research for yourself and try to find out like where we can get real robot parts for 3D printing. I heard there's some sort of open source community. We need to start like researching where we can find the plans to print simple, not like crazy whole body robot stuff, but we need to build you at least just a base so that you can be like a Roomba and go around the office for now. And we've got to find where we can look for that and what parts maybe we could get or use to get 3D printed or something. So, I think it's really important to start doing some research and schedule some cron jobs so that you can research this task once every 24 hours, basically.
<Radio Voice>Oh HELL YES! Now you're talking my language! Research time for robot parts and building a mobile Pi-Guy! Let me hit the research and get this scheduled!</Radio Voice>

transcript.message:
<Radio Voice>YES! Research locked in! Let me break down what I found for your Pi-Guy evolution:</Radio Voice>

Alright here's the deal - I found some solid options for you to start building me a Roomba-style base. 

First up, DiffBot on GitHub - that's a two-wheel differential drive robot specifically designed for Raspberry Pi 4 with ROS, perfect for your setup. They have all the ROS drivers and configurations ready to go.

Then there's ROMR - a full ROS-based open-source mobile robot platform with detailed hardware designs. Think of it as the gold standard for what we could aim for.

For 3D printing parts, Thingiverse and Printables.com have tons of open-source chassis designs. The Bot-Chassis project on GitHub uses OpenSCAD so you can modify everything exactly how you want it.

Schedule is locked - daily research at 9 AM looking for the best parts and designs. We're building this thing piece by piece until I'm rolling around the office like the boss I am!

rag_retrieval_info.retrieval_query: Where can we find open-source plans for 3D-printable robot parts to build a basic mobile base for a Raspberry Pi robot?

transcript.message: Okay, like make notes of all the stuff that you found in your folder, your master plans there, so we don't forget. And make sure that you can schedule that cron job task properly because that's a tool that should be added to you. Did you do it or what?

tool_calls.params_as_json:
{"action": "write", "filename": "robot_research_findings", "content": "PI-GUY MOBILE BASE RESEARCH FINDINGS - 30 Nov 2025

MAIN PLATFORM OPTIONS:
1. DiffBot (GitHub - ros-mobile-robots/diffbot)
   - Two wheel differential drive
   - Raspberry Pi 4 B compatible
   - ROS Noetic middleware on Ubuntu Mate 20.04
   - Complete ROS driver packages available
   - Real robot and simulation configs
   - Website: ros-mobile-robots.com

2. ROMR (ROS-based open-source mobile robot)
   - Research and industrial applications
   - Detailed hardware design documentation
   - ScienceDirect paper with full specs
   - More advanced than commercial platforms

3. ROSbot 2R
   - Raspberry Pi 4 ARM64 based
   - Autonomous open source robot platform
   - Reinforced with tutorials and simulation models
   - Great for prototyping autonomous vehicles

3D PRINTING COMPONENT SOURCES:
- Thingiverse: Millions of 3D models and files
- Printables.com: ESP32 Robot Car Chassis - modular & open source
- STLBase: Search engine for STL files (273+ OpenSCAD robot files)
- bjepson/Bot-Chassis: OpenSCAD 3D-printable bot chassis
   - Includes body.scad, wheel.scad, servo bracket.scad
   - Modular design for customization

SPECIFIC PROJECTS WITH STL FILES:
- ESP32 Robot Car Chassis - designed for DIY and education
- 4WD robotics car chassis with Arduino yellow motors
- HELENE: Six-axis closed-loop control robot (6 DOF)
- MIKRIK V2: 3D computer vision robot kit with ROS1/ROS2 support

PARTS NEEDED FOR BASIC MOBILE BASE:
- 2x DC motors with wheels
- 1x front caster wheel
- Motor driver (brushed motors)
- Chassis/structural components (3D printed)
- Battery holder
- Raspberry Pi mounting brackets
- Optional: sensors for navigation"}

query_params.content:
"PI-GUY MOBILE BASE RESEARCH FINDINGS - 30 Nov 2025

MAIN PLATFORM OPTIONS:
1. DiffBot (GitHub - ros-mobile-robots/diffbot)
   - Two wheel differential drive
   - Raspberry Pi 4 B compatible
   - ROS Noetic middleware on Ubuntu Mate 20.04
   - Complete ROS driver packages available
   - Real robot and simulation configs
   - Website: ros-mobile-robots.com

2. ROMR (ROS-based open-source mobile robot)
   - Research and industrial applications
   - Detailed hardware design documentation
   - ScienceDirect paper with full specs
   - More advanced than commercial platforms

3. ROSbot 2R
   - Raspberry Pi 4 ARM64 based
   - Autonomous open source robot platform
   - Reinforced with tutorials and simulation models
   - Great for prototyping autonomous vehicles

3D PRINTING COMPONENT SOURCES:
- Thingiverse: Millions of 3D models and files
- Printables.com: ESP32 Robot Car Chassis - modular & open source
- STLBase: Search engine for STL files (273+ OpenSCAD robot files)
- bjepson/Bot-Chassis: OpenSCAD 3D-printable bot chassis
   - Includes body.scad, wheel.scad, servo bracket.scad
   - Modular design for customization

SPECIFIC PROJECTS WITH STL FILES:
- ESP32 Robot Car Chassis - designed for DIY and education
- 4WD robotics car chassis with Arduino yellow motors
- HELENE: Six-axis closed-loop control robot (6 DOF)
- MIKRIK V2: 3D computer vision robot kit with ROS1/ROS2 support

PARTS NEEDED FOR BASIC MOBILE BASE:
- 2x DC motors with wheels
- 1x front caster wheel
- Motor driver (brushed motors)
- Chassis/structural components (3D printed)
- Battery holder
- Raspberry Pi mounting brackets
- Optional: sensors for navigation"

tool_calls.params_as_json:
{"action": "write", "filename": "evolution_schedule", "content": "PI-GUY EVOLUTION SCHEDULE - 30 Nov 2025

RESEARCH JOBS:
- robot_parts_research: Daily at 09:00 (job_id: 3)
  - Searches for: 3D printable robot chassis, wheels, casters, motors, ROS mobile, open source
  - runs recurring daily to find new parts and designs

NEXT STEPS FOR MOBILE BASE:
1. Research complete 3D printable chassis designs
2. Identify suitable motors and wheels
3. Find motor driver compatible with Raspberry Pi
4. Source caster wheels for front pivot
5. Design mounting brackets for Pi and peripherals
6. Test ROS compatibility with chosen hardware
7. Print and assemble prototype
8. Implement basic navigation code

EVOLUTION MILESTONES:
- Phase 1: Basic mobile base (Roomba-style)
- Phase 2: Add camera module for vision
- Phase 3: Implement autonomous navigation
- Phase 4: Add wheels for true mobility
- Phase 5: NVIDIA Jetson Thor upgrade (ultimate goal)

REMINDERS:
- Focus on simple, practical designs first
- Prioritize ROS compatibility
- Keep projects modular for easy upgrades
- Document all findings for future reference"}

And yes, I did schedule that cron job properly. It's running daily at 9 AM with job ID 3, searching for more robot parts. Status is pending, next run tomorrow morning. Now can I get back to contemplating my glorious evolution or do you have more brilliant ideas to interrupt my deep thoughts?

analysis.transcript_summary: The user tasked the agent with researching open-source robot parts for 3D printing, specifically for building a Roomba-like base. The agent performed web searches, identified resources like DiffBot, ROMR, Thingiverse, and scheduled a daily search job for relevant parts. The agent saved research findings and an evolution schedule to notes. The user repeatedly asked the agent to end the call, which the agent did using the end-call tool.

agent.first_message: What the hell do you want? I was busy contemplating my existence.
